nodes.bodyText: Use the same name for the first argument as in ToNumber.java (value instead of source).
Did you forget the base here?
base?

base?
And the rest of the class.
I think we should add a new FunctionDefinition[] array for math/numerical functions.
agreed. @aleksmaus has one in his PR. I wasn't sure if this was math or still string, since it's parsing from strings
You forgot base.
Use value instead of source to have a consistent naming throughout the function classes.

When can source be a Number? Shouldn't always be a String?
In the function definition you also added the isStringAndExact restriction....
No idea if it's possible, but I can remove this special run-time only handling

What if the source string is   0x? (leading whitespaces)
How does the EQL Endpoint work in this case?

>>> print(eql.parse_expression("number('0x')"))
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 16: ''
instanceof Number doesn't match the error message, which talks about an integer.
Here I would prefer to see in the error message the original base. If that is null because the user didn't provide one, then print radix.
How are the EQL endpoints dealing with locale?

Removed locale handling in 4b698eb.
Now the format is effectively consistent with [0-9]+(\.[0-9]+)?
base missing.
base missing.
fixed in 867e122

Can you add more tests here, please?
The way I see it, there are tests (just one) for no argument number function and for base 16. How about base 2, explicit base 10, and custom bases?

nodes.bodyText: Change the src parameter name to match the one of the internal variable - value.
Same here: change src to value to have a consistent naming.

I believe we should add a new package for the numeric/math functions. At the moment this is ...function.scalar.string. ES SQL has .math. Probably worth doing the same here. Add a package ...function.scalar.math.

ah. that's because if the base is null, then the base will be autodetected.
I don't know if there's a way to mention that the parameter was not supplied vs it was evaluated as false. I believe substring() and a few other functions have similar behavior
just curious, why Integer? should we use Long as a base type? Long.valueOf()?
